interface.name: org.freedesktop.Telepathy.Channel.Interface.MediaSignalling

tp:simple-type.name: Media_Session_Type
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring: The type of a media session. Currently, the only supported value is "rtp".

tp:struct.name: Media_Session_Handler_Info
tp:struct.tp:docstring: A struct representing a active session handler.

tp:member.name: Session_Handler
tp:member.tp:docstring: The object path of the session handler, which is on the same bus name as the channel.

method.name: GetSessionHandlers
method.tp:docstring: Returns all currently active session handlers on this channel as a list of (session_handler_path, type).

signal.name: NewSessionHandler

arg.name: Session_Handler
arg.tp:docstring: Object path of the new MediaSessionHandler object

arg.name: Session_Type
arg.tp:docstring: String indicating type of session, eg "rtp"

signal.tp:docstring: Signal that a session handler object has been created. The client should create a session object and create streams for the streams within.

tp:docstring.p: A string indicating the NAT traversal techniques employed by the streams within this channel. Can be protocol-specific values, but the following values should be used if appropriate:

dl.dd: No attempt should be made at NAT traversal.
If appropriate, a STUN request should be made to the given server to open a UDP port mapping and determine the external IP.
Google Talk peer-to-peer connectivity establishment should be used, as implemented in libjingle 0.3.

tp:property.name: stun-server
tp:property.tp:docstring: The IP address or hostname of the STUN server to use for NAT traversal.

tp:property.name: stun-port
tp:property.tp:docstring: The UDP port number to use on the provided STUN server.

tp:property.name: gtalk-p2p-relay-token
tp:property.tp:docstring: The authentication token for use with the Google Talk peer-to-peer relay server.

interface.tp:docstring: An interface for signalling a channel containing synchronised media sessions which can contain an arbitrary number of streams. The negotiation interface is based closely around the API of the Farsight library (http://farsight.sourceforge.net/). This in turn is based upon the IETF MMusic ICE drafts where connections are established by signalling potential connection candidates to the peer until a usable connection is found, and codecs are negotiated with an SDP-style offer and answer. However, the principles should be applicable to other media streaming methods and the API re-used without difficulty.
